content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Elizabeth Ong: I was born and raised in Providence, Rhode Island, in a small, close-knit Irish-American family. My parents worked hard to provide for us, though we never had much money growing up. My father had an associate's degree in engineering, and he worked as a mechanic, while my mother, who only finished high school, worked part-time as a clerk at a local store. We lived in a modest home on Elm Street, and I remember my childhood being filled with the sounds of my mother's voice reading stories to me before bed and my father tinkering with old cars in the garage. I always felt a strong sense of community in Providence, and I was lucky to have a stable family life, even if we weren't wealthy. I was a good student, though I didn't have access to many resources. I went to college on a scholarship, eventually earning a graduate degree in social work, which led me to the job I have now. I married my husband, Michael, in our early 30s, and we've been raising our two kids in the same neighborhood I grew up in. Life hasn't been easy, but I've always believed in working hard and staying grounded.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Elizabeth Ong: Yes, there was a moment that really shaped my life. I was in my second year of college, studying for my bachelor's degree, and I had the chance to either stay in my local community college or transfer to a larger university in Boston. I was really torn because I wanted to be close to my family and the support system I had, but I also knew that the bigger university had better resources and more opportunities. In the end, I chose to stay local, and that decision was both a blessing and a challenge. I had to work part-time while going to school, which made things harder, but it also taught me resilience and the value of community. Looking back, I think that choice helped me stay grounded and connected to my roots, which has been important in my career in social work. I often tell my students that sometimes the path that seems smaller is the one that leads you to the right place at the right time.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Elizabeth Ong: I think it was a conscious choice, though it didn't feel like one at the time. I remember sitting at my kitchen table, staring at the application for the university in Boston, and feeling this mix of excitement and fear. I knew if I left, I might not come back, and I wasn't sure I could handle being so far from home. My parents were supportive, but they also didn't have the means to help me move or support me financially if I left. I felt like I was being pulled in two directions — the pull of opportunity and the pull of family. In the end, I made a decision that felt right for me then, even if it wasn't the easiest path. I think that's what makes life meaningful — making choices that align with who you are, even when they're hard.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Elizabeth Ong: Yes, I think someone or something could have helped. My high school counselor was actually very supportive and encouraged me to apply to the university in Boston, but I didn't feel ready to take that step. I think I was afraid of leaving everything I knew behind. Looking back, I wish I had reached out more to people in my community or maybe even sought out financial aid resources that I wasn't aware of at the time. But I also think that the challenges I faced helped shape who I am today. I learned the importance of perseverance and the strength that comes from staying close to the people you love. In my work as a social worker, I always try to remind others that it's okay to ask for help — sometimes the right support can make all the difference.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Elizabeth Ong: Yes, I have a partner and two children. My husband, Michael, is a teacher at the local high school, and we met through a mutual friend when I was volunteering at the community center. We got married in our early 30s, after both of us had taken some time to figure out what we wanted in life. Our children, Liam and Sophie, are 8 and 5, and they live with us in the same neighborhood I grew up in. It's important to me to raise them close to family and in the community that shaped me. My mother still lives just a few blocks away, and she helps out with the kids whenever she can. I think having that support system is something I value deeply, especially since I know what it's like to grow up without a lot of resources. Being a mother has been one of the most rewarding experiences of my life, though it's also incredibly challenging. I often reflect on how my own childhood influenced the way I parent — I want my kids to feel safe, loved, and encouraged to dream big, even if we don't have a lot.

Going through the interview questions made me reflect on how much my life has been shaped by the choices I've made, especially the ones that weren't easy. Talking about my childhood, my education, and the crossroads I faced in college brought back a lot of memories. I realized how much my family and community have been a constant source of strength, even when I didn't have the resources others might have had. It's interesting to look back and see how staying close to home, even when it meant more challenges, helped me become the person I am today. Being a mother now, I see how important it is to give my children the same sense of stability and support that I had growing up. I'm grateful for the path I've taken, even with its struggles, because it's led me to where I am now — someone who can help others navigate their own challenges, just as I was once helped.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Elizabeth Ong: My immediate family includes my younger brother, Patrick, who is 12 years younger than me. He lives in Massachusetts now, where he works as a carpenter. We're very close, even though we don't see each other as often as I'd like. He was always the adventurous one growing up, and I think that's why he ended up moving away. We talk often on the phone, and whenever he comes back to visit, we spend days catching up and reminiscing about our childhood. My parents are still very much a part of my life, and I feel lucky to have them nearby. My father, though he's retired now, still enjoys fixing things around the house, and my mother keeps a close eye on the kids when I'm busy with work. Our family has always been about support and love, and I think that's something I carry with me every day in my job as a social worker. I believe that the strength of my family is one of the reasons I've been able to overcome so many challenges in my life.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Elizabeth Ong: Yes, there are a few friends who have been important to me over the years. One of them is Sarah, who I met in college. She was one of the few people who encouraged me to pursue social work, even when I wasn't sure I had the confidence to do it. We've been friends for over 20 years now, and even though she moved to California a few years back, we stay in touch through letters and video calls. She's the one who always reminds me that I'm capable of more than I sometimes believe. Then there's my husband's best friend, James, who's been like a brother to me. He's the one who helped me fix my car when I first moved out on my own, and he's always there with advice or a shoulder to lean on. I think having people in your life who believe in you, even when you don't believe in yourself, is one of the most important things. It's those relationships that help you keep going when things get tough.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Elizabeth Ong: I live in a neighborhood that feels like a piece of home — the same streets I grew up on, the same sense of community that shaped me. Providence has always had a mix of old and new, with historic buildings standing next to modern apartments, and I love that about it. There's a small park just a few blocks from my house where the kids play, and it's the same one I used to run through as a child. The people here are friendly, and there's always someone willing to lend a hand, whether it's a neighbor helping with a broken fence or someone stopping by to check in on you when you're having a tough day. I think that's why I chose to raise my family here — because I want my kids to know what it's like to be part of something bigger than themselves. Even though the area isn't the wealthiest, there's a real sense of pride and resilience among the residents. It's not perfect, but it's real, and I feel like I'm giving my children the same kind of foundation I had — one built on hard work, community, and the belief that you can make a difference, no matter where you come from.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Elizabeth Ong: I feel pretty safe here, though I know it's not the kind of safety that comes with high fences or gated communities. It's more of a quiet, unspoken kind of safety — the kind that comes from knowing your neighbors, from having people who look out for one another. There have been times when I've walked home late at night and seen someone I know standing on their porch, waving or calling out to make sure I'm okay. That kind of care makes a difference. I've also had moments where I've felt the weight of the neighborhood's challenges — the struggles with poverty, the occasional conflict, the lack of resources — but I think that's what makes the safety here even more meaningful. It's not about being protected from everything, but about being part of something that supports you through it all. I want my kids to grow up knowing that safety isn't just about being shielded from harm, but about being surrounded by people who care enough to help when things get tough.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Elizabeth Ong: Living here has had its ups and downs, just like anywhere else. On the one hand, I love the sense of belonging and the way the community feels like a second family. There's a rhythm to life here that I've always found comforting — the same streets, the same local shops, the same friendly faces. But it's not without its challenges. There are days when I see the struggles of the people around me, the ones who don't have the same opportunities I had, and it weighs on me. I've worked in social work long enough to know that poverty isn't just about money — it's about access, about resources, about feeling like you're stuck in a cycle. Still, I believe in this place. I believe in the resilience of the people here, and I believe that even in the hardest times, there's always a way forward. For me, living here means staying connected to my roots, to the values that shaped me, and to the people who have supported me through every step of my life.

Going through the interview questions about my family, neighborhood, and sense of safety brought up a lot of feelings I hadn't fully processed before. Talking about my husband, children, and parents reminded me how much my family has been the foundation of my life — the same way my own family was for me growing up. It's interesting how much I value the sense of community in this neighborhood, even with its challenges. I've always believed that safety isn't just about being protected, but about being surrounded by people who care. It's something I try to pass on to my kids, just as I was given it. I think that's why I chose to stay in this neighborhood — because I want my children to know what it's like to belong to something bigger than themselves, even if it's not perfect. It's a reminder that home isn't just a place, but a feeling, and I'm grateful for the life I've built here.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Elizabeth Ong: A typical week for me is pretty structured, though it varies depending on work and family needs. I start most mornings around 6:30 a.m., making sure the kids are up, fed, and ready for school. My husband usually gets up a bit later, so I handle the morning routine most days. I work full time as a social worker at a community center, so I leave the house by 8 a.m. and am usually back by 5 or 6 p.m. After work, I pick up the kids, and we have dinner together. On weekdays, I try to spend some time helping with homework or just talking with them about their day. On the weekends, we like to go to the park, visit my parents, or sometimes take a short trip to the beach if the weather is nice. I also make time for myself — whether it's reading, going for a walk, or just sitting in the garden and thinking. Life is busy, but I try to keep a balance because I know how important it is to be present for my family and to take care of myself, too.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Elizabeth Ong: I work full time as a social worker at a community center here in Providence, and I'm usually on the clock from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m., Monday through Friday. My job is pretty varied — some days I'm helping families navigate housing assistance, other days I'm counseling individuals dealing with mental health issues or domestic challenges. I also run a small support group for single parents, which is something I'm really passionate about. It's a demanding job, but it's also incredibly rewarding. I get to work with people who are often at their lowest points, and it reminds me of the struggles I faced growing up. I think that's why I'm so committed to this work — because I know what it's like to need help, and I want to be the kind of person who shows up for others the way my community showed up for me. It's not always easy, but I believe in the impact we can have, even in small ways.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Elizabeth Ong: Outside of work and family, I also have a few other routines that keep me grounded. I've always had a love for baking, and I try to make something from scratch at least a few times a week — whether it's bread, cookies, or even just a simple cake for the kids. It's my way of slowing down and being present, especially after a long day. I also volunteer at the local food pantry on weekends, which is something I've been doing for several years now. It's not just about giving back; it's about staying connected to the community and remembering where I came from. I think those small, consistent acts of kindness — whether it's baking for my family or helping someone in need — are what keep me feeling like I'm making a difference, even on the days when everything else feels overwhelming.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Elizabeth Ong: One of the recent changes to my daily routine has been taking on more evening shifts at the community center, which means I'm often home later than usual. It's been a bit of an adjustment, especially with the kids, but I've found that it gives me more time in the mornings to prepare meals or catch up on reading before the day starts. I've also started walking to work instead of driving, just to get some fresh air and clear my head. It's a small change, but it's made a big difference in how I feel throughout the day. Plus, it's given me a chance to see more of the neighborhood and connect with people I might not have crossed paths with otherwise. I think these little shifts, while not dramatic, help keep life from feeling too predictable — and that's something I value, especially with everything else going on.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Elizabeth Ong: During the school year, my kids have a pretty structured routine. They wake up around 7 a.m., have a quick breakfast, and then head off to school. Both of them are in the same school, which is just a few blocks away from our house. After school, they usually have some time to play outside or in the park before heading to after-school activities. Liam is in a soccer program twice a week, and Sophie has a weekly art class at the community center. I try to make sure they have some time to unwind and be kids, but I also want them to have opportunities to explore their interests. On the days they don't have activities, we often have homework time in the evening, and I sit with them to help with their assignments. It's not always easy — there are days when they're frustrated or tired — but I think it's important for them to learn how to manage their time and responsibilities. I also make sure they have dinner with us every night, because I believe in the value of family meals, even if it's just a simple meal. It's those little moments that help them feel grounded and connected to home.

Going through the interview topics from questions 11 to 15 made me reflect on how deeply my sense of belonging and purpose is tied to the people and place I call home. Talking about my family, neighborhood, and daily routines reminded me of how much I value the stability and support that have shaped my life. It also made me think about the importance of balance — between work, family, and self-care — and how even small routines, like baking or walking to work, can bring meaning to an otherwise busy life. I realized how much I want to pass on the same sense of community and resilience to my children, just as I was given it. It's comforting to know that even in the challenges of life, there's always a way forward, and that home is not just a place, but a feeling rooted in love, connection, and the people who stand by you.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Elizabeth Ong: In terms of my health, I'd say I'm generally in pretty good shape, though I've had my share of challenges over the years. I've always been active, even as a child — I loved running around the neighborhood, playing in the park, and helping my father with small repairs around the house. That physical activity has carried over into adulthood, and I try to stay as active as I can, whether it's walking to work, taking the kids to the park, or even just doing some light stretching in the morning. That said, I've dealt with some chronic back pain from years of lifting and bending, especially when I was working part-time in college and helping out at home. I see a chiropractor every few months, and I've learned to listen to my body when it's telling me to slow down. I also try to eat as healthily as I can, even with a busy schedule — I make sure to cook meals at home whenever I can, and I try to limit processed foods. I know that taking care of my health is important, not just for myself, but for my kids too. I want to be there for them, and I believe that being healthy is one of the best ways I can show them how to take care of themselves as they grow up.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Elizabeth Ong: What makes it easy to stay healthy for me is having a routine that's rooted in the things I've always done — like walking, cooking at home, and staying connected to the people and places I love. Those habits feel natural to me, almost like part of who I am. But what makes it hard is the constant balancing act between work, family, and self-care. There are days when I'm so caught up in helping others or juggling the needs of my kids that I forget to take a moment for myself. I've learned that I need to be intentional about it — setting aside time to rest, to move my body, and to eat well, even when life gets overwhelming. It's not always easy, but I know that if I don't take care of myself, I won't be able to take care of anyone else the way I want to.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Elizabeth Ong: In the past two years, I've had a few health challenges that reminded me just how important it is to take care of myself. About a year ago, I started experiencing more frequent flare-ups of the back pain I've dealt with for years. It got to the point where I was having trouble bending down to pick up the kids or even sitting for long periods at work. I finally made an appointment with my doctor, and she confirmed that the pain was related to old injuries from when I was working part-time in college and helping out around the house. She recommended physical therapy, which I started, and it's been helping — though it's been a slow process. I also had a minor fall last winter while walking on an icy patch near the park, which gave me a sprained ankle. It wasn't serious, but it was a reminder that I need to be more careful, especially as I get older. Overall, these experiences have made me more aware of my body and more committed to taking the time to rest and recover when I need to. I've started incorporating more gentle stretching into my daily routine and have been more mindful of how I lift things, especially when I'm helping the kids with their homework or doing chores around the house. It's not perfect, but I'm learning that taking care of my health is a daily practice — one that I need to keep up with, just like everything else in life.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Elizabeth Ong: Honestly, there have been moments when my health issues made things harder, especially when the back pain flared up and I had to take a step back from work or from helping the kids with their daily routines. I remember one week when I was so sore that I had to sit down during my lunch break just to catch my breath. It was humbling, because I've always prided myself on being strong and capable — not just for my job, but for my family. But what I've learned is that being strong doesn't mean never needing help. I've had to ask my husband to take over more of the household chores, and I've had to be more honest with my boss about when I need to slow down. It's not easy, but it's taught me that taking care of myself isn't selfish — it's necessary. If I can't be there for my kids or my work, then I'm not being the kind of mother or social worker I want to be. I've also started relying more on my support system — my parents, my brother, even my friends — to help me through the tough days. It's a reminder that no one has to go through life alone, and that even when things get hard, there's always a way forward — as long as you're willing to ask for help.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Elizabeth Ong: Over the past year, I've had a lot of mixed emotions — there's been both growth and struggle. On one hand, I feel more grounded than ever in my role as a mother and a social worker. I've started to find a better balance between my work and my family, and I've learned to be more patient with myself when things don't go perfectly. I've also been really grateful for the support I've received from my husband, my parents, and my friends, especially during the times when my back pain flared up and I needed to slow down. But there have also been moments of deep exhaustion, both physically and emotionally. Raising two kids, working full time, and trying to stay healthy while also helping others in my community can be overwhelming at times. I've had to confront some of my own limitations and accept that I can't do everything on my own. That's been a hard lesson, but it's also been a kind of freedom — knowing that it's okay to lean on others, to ask for help, and to take time for myself when I need it. I think the past year has been a reminder that life is a constant process of learning, adapting, and finding strength in the people around you — even when things feel heavy.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 16 to 20 made me reflect on how much my daily routines and health are intertwined with the people and place I call home. Talking about the small changes in my schedule, like taking evening shifts and walking to work, reminded me how even the smallest shifts can bring a sense of balance and clarity to an otherwise busy life. It also made me think about how my health, though not perfect, is something I'm learning to take more seriously — not just for myself, but for my family. I've come to understand that taking care of my body is just as important as taking care of my kids or my job. These reflections have helped me see that health isn't just about avoiding illness, but about being present, being strong, and being able to show up for the people I love — even on the days when I'm not feeling my best.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Elizabeth Ong: I think I've experienced moments of anxiety, especially during the times when I felt like I was juggling too much — work, family, health, and trying to be there for others. There were days when I would wake up feeling like I had to be everything to everyone, and that pressure would weigh on me. I remember one particular winter when the back pain was really bad, and I was also dealing with a heavy caseload at work. I felt like I was failing at being the strong, capable person I wanted to be. But what I've come to understand is that anxiety isn't always about something huge — it can be about the everyday stress of trying to keep everything together. I've started talking more openly about how I feel with my husband and my friends, and I've also begun practicing mindfulness and deep breathing when I feel overwhelmed. It's not a perfect solution, but it's helped me recognize when I need to pause and take a step back. I think the most important thing I've learned is that it's okay to not be okay — and that asking for help is a sign of strength, not weakness.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Elizabeth Ong: For my family, it's been a mix of challenges and moments of deep connection. My husband has been my rock, especially during the times when I've been struggling with my health or feeling overwhelmed by work. He's taken on more responsibilities at home, and I'm so grateful for his patience and support. Our kids have also been resilient — they've learned to adapt to our routines and have become more independent, which is something I'm really proud of. Sophie, in particular, has been asking a lot of questions about why I sometimes have to rest or why I can't do certain things, and it's made me reflect on how important it is to be honest with them about my limitations. I think they're learning that it's okay to have hard days, and that asking for help is a sign of strength, not weakness. My parents have also been a huge support — they're always there to help with the kids or just to listen when I need to talk. I think the past year has brought us closer together, even though it's been tough. It's reminded me that family isn't just about being perfect — it's about showing up for each other, even when things are hard.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Elizabeth Ong: For me, religion has always been a quiet but steady presence in my life. I was raised Catholic, and even though I don't attend Mass as often as I used to, the values I learned growing up — like kindness, compassion, and the importance of community — still shape the way I live. My faith has been especially important during the harder times, like when I was struggling with my health or feeling overwhelmed by work and family. I find comfort in the idea that there's something bigger than myself, even if I don't always feel close to God in a traditional sense. I also appreciate the sense of belonging that comes with being part of a faith community, even if it's not something I engage with every week. For my kids, I want them to know that faith is about more than just going to church — it's about living with integrity, showing love to others, and finding strength in the things that matter most. I think that's why I still keep a small crucifix on my kitchen table — it's a reminder of where I came from and the values that have always guided me.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Elizabeth Ong: To be honest, I don't use social media very often — maybe a few times a week to check in with friends or see what's going on in my family's lives. I find that the more I stay connected to the people around me in person, the less I feel the need to be online. I do have a Facebook account, mostly to keep in touch with my brother in Massachusetts and some old friends from college, but I don't spend a lot of time scrolling through feeds or comparing my life to others. I think social media can be a double-edged sword — it's great for staying connected, but it can also make you feel like you're missing out on things or like you're not enough. I've seen how it can affect people's mental health, especially young people, and I want my kids to grow up understanding that their worth isn't tied to likes or followers. Instead, I prefer to spend my time talking to people face-to-face, whether it's at the park, the grocery store, or just sitting on my porch with a cup of coffee. I think there's something real and grounding about being present in the moment, and I try to keep that in mind even when I do use social media.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Elizabeth Ong: Honestly, I haven't relied much on social media for support during tough times — not because I don't think it can be helpful, but because I've always found strength in the people I know in person. When I was going through my back pain or feeling overwhelmed with work, it was my husband, my parents, or my friends who showed up for me, not a post or a message. That said, I do think social media can be a tool for connection, especially for people who might not have a strong support system in their immediate lives. I've seen friends use it to share their struggles and find encouragement from others going through similar things. For me, though, I prefer to lean on the people I already know and trust. I think there's something about face-to-face support that feels more real, more grounding. It's not that I don't believe in the power of online communities — I just know what works for me, and it's the people who are right here, right now, in my life.

Going through the interview topics from questions 21 to 25 made me reflect on how much my health and emotional well-being are deeply connected to the people and routines in my life. Talking about my recent health challenges, like the back pain and the sprained ankle, reminded me how important it is to listen to my body and take the time to rest and recover. It also made me think about how my anxiety and the pressure of juggling work, family, and self-care have affected me, and how I've had to learn to ask for help when I need it. I've come to understand that being strong doesn't mean being perfect — it means being honest about my struggles and relying on the support of my husband, my parents, and my friends. These reflections have helped me see that my health and emotional well-being aren't just personal matters, but they're also about showing up for my kids and my work in the best way I can, even on the days when I'm not feeling my strongest.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Elizabeth Ong: In the past year, I've noticed my stress levels have shifted — some days feel lighter, and others feel heavier, depending on how I'm balancing everything. I think the biggest change has been in how I cope with that stress. Before, I used to push through it, thinking that if I just worked harder or stayed busy, I could handle anything. But lately, I've been learning to pause and breathe when I feel overwhelmed. I've started journaling more, just to get my thoughts out and make sense of what's going on. I also find that talking things through with my husband or my parents helps a lot — they've always been good at listening without judgment. I've even tried some gentle yoga in the evenings, which has been a nice way to unwind after a long day. It's not always easy to slow down, especially when there's so much to do, but I'm starting to see that taking time to care for my emotional well-being is just as important as taking care of my body. I think that's one of the lessons I want to pass on to my kids — that it's okay to feel stressed, but it's also important to find healthy ways to manage it.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Elizabeth Ong: Last month, our biggest expenses were rent, groceries, and the kids' school supplies. We live in a modest two-bedroom apartment, and the rent takes up about a third of our income. Groceries are another big one — especially with two kids who are always hungry, and I try to feed them well even on a budget. We also had to pay for Liam's soccer gear and Sophie's art class, which are things I know are important for their development, even if they're not cheap. I also set aside money each month for my chiropractor visits and any unexpected medical costs, just in case. We don't have a lot, but we manage — mostly because we're careful and because my husband and I both work. I think the thing that helps the most is knowing that we're not alone. My parents help out when they can, and I volunteer at the food pantry, which gives me a sense of purpose and also helps me stay connected to the community. It's not always easy, but I believe that with a little planning and a lot of love, we can make it work.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Elizabeth Ong: Last month, our household spent around $2,800, which is pretty much in line with what we usually spend each month. The breakdown is pretty standard for us — about $900 on rent, $700 on groceries, and another $500 on the kids' activities and school supplies. We also set aside around $300 for utilities, insurance, and my chiropractor visits. The rest goes toward miscellaneous expenses like transportation, clothing, and savings. We don't have a lot of extra money, but we manage by being careful with what we spend and by relying on the support of family and community. I think what helps the most is knowing that we're not alone — my parents help out when they can, and I volunteer at the food pantry, which gives me a sense of purpose and also helps me stay connected to the people around me. It's not always easy, but I believe that with a little planning and a lot of love, we can make it work.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Elizabeth Ong: We rent our home — it's a two-bedroom apartment just a few blocks from where I grew up. Renting has always been the practical choice for us, especially with the way the housing market is here in Providence. We don't have the savings to buy a home, and even if we did, I think I'd rather keep my money liquid in case something unexpected comes up, like medical bills or a sudden need for childcare. Renting also gives us more flexibility, which is something I appreciate, especially with the way life can change so quickly. I know it's not the most stable option, but for now, it works for us. Plus, being close to my parents and the community I know so well makes it feel like home, even if it's just an apartment.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Elizabeth Ong: Over the past year, our bills have had their ups and downs, just like the rest of life. For example, during the winter months, our heating bill went up quite a bit, which is something we're used to in Providence — the cold can be brutal. We also had a few unexpected expenses, like when Liam needed new soccer cleats mid-season and Sophie's art class had a special materials fee. On the other hand, there were times when we saved a bit more, like during the summer when we didn't need as much heating and we were able to buy groceries in bulk. I also noticed that our utility bills tend to be higher in the summer because we use the air conditioner more, especially with the kids running around the house and the apartment not being the most energy-efficient. But what's interesting is that even with these fluctuations, we've managed to stay on track by budgeting carefully and relying on the support of our community. I think the biggest thing that helps us is knowing that we're not alone — whether it's my parents helping out with a few extra dollars or the food pantry giving us a hand when we need it most. It's all part of the rhythm of life here, and I've learned to roll with the changes, just like I did growing up.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 26 to 30 made me reflect on how deeply my family and personal connections are tied to my emotional and mental well-being. Talking about my health struggles, anxiety, and how my family has supported me reminded me of how important it is to be honest about my limitations and to lean on the people I love. It also made me think about how my faith, though not always practiced in a traditional way, has been a quiet source of strength for me, especially during difficult times. I've come to understand that my worth isn't tied to being perfect or having everything together — it's about showing up for my family, being kind to myself, and finding comfort in the values that have shaped me. It's also made me more aware of how social media, while not a big part of my life, can be a double-edged sword for others, and I'm grateful that I've always found support in the people I know in person rather than online. These reflections have helped me see that my emotional well-being is not just about managing stress or staying healthy — it's about being connected to the people and values that ground me, even when life feels overwhelming.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Elizabeth Ong: I do have a savings account, though it's not a lot — maybe around $1,500 at the moment. It's not much, but it's there for emergencies, like if one of us gets sick or if something unexpected comes up with the kids. I think the most important thing is that we're not living paycheck to paycheck, even if we're not saving a huge amount. I also try to set aside a little bit each month for small things, like a new pair of shoes for Sophie or a special treat for Liam. It's not about having a lot, but about being prepared and knowing that we can handle whatever comes our way. I've learned that saving doesn't have to be about big numbers — it's about being responsible and thinking ahead, even when life feels uncertain. I think that's something I want my kids to understand too — that it's not about having everything, but about making smart choices and being ready for the future.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Elizabeth Ong: For me, saving has always been more about the rainy day kind of thing — just making sure we have a little cushion in case something unexpected happens. I don't think I've ever really saved for a big purchase like a home, mostly because I know that's not something we're going to be able to afford anytime soon. But I do try to set aside a little bit each month for things like emergencies or even small family goals, like a weekend trip or a special event. It's not about having a lot, but about being prepared and knowing that we can handle whatever comes our way. I think that's something I want my kids to understand too — that it's not about having everything, but about making smart choices and being ready for the future.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Elizabeth Ong: My occupation has always been centered around helping others, which is why I became a social worker. In my role at the community center, I work closely with families who are facing a wide range of challenges — from housing instability to mental health struggles. Each day is different, but the most important part of my job is listening. I think people often forget how powerful it is to be heard, especially when they're going through something difficult. Whether it's a single parent trying to make ends meet, a teenager dealing with anxiety, or an elderly person who feels isolated, I try to approach each situation with empathy and understanding. I also run a small support group for single parents, which is something I'm really passionate about. It's not always easy — there are days when I feel overwhelmed by the weight of other people's struggles — but I believe in the impact we can have, even in small ways. For me, this work isn't just a job; it's a calling. It's the same kind of support I received growing up, and I want to be that kind of person for others — someone who shows up, who listens, and who believes in the possibility of change, no matter how small.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Elizabeth Ong: I usually work around 40 hours a week, though the days can vary depending on the needs of the community center and my caseload. Some weeks I'm in the office from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m., while other weeks I might have to stay late for meetings or support group sessions. I also take on some evening shifts now and then, especially when there's a need for extra coverage. It's not always a nine-to-five job, but I've learned to manage my time as best as I can. I try to leave work at a reasonable hour so I can be there for my kids, even if it means working a few extra hours on other days. It's a balance, but one I've come to accept as part of the job — and part of being a mother and a community member. I think that's what makes it meaningful for me — knowing that my work, however many hours it takes, is making a difference in someone's life, just as my own community helped me when I needed it most.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Elizabeth Ong: No, I haven't had more than one job — at least not in the traditional sense. My work as a social worker is my full-time commitment, and I've always believed that giving your best to one role is important, especially when you're trying to be present for your family. That said, I do take on some additional responsibilities that aren't paid, like volunteering at the food pantry on weekends or helping out with neighborhood events. I also find myself stepping in to help friends or family members in need, whether it's babysitting for a few hours or helping someone with a small repair around the house. I think those things are part of the fabric of life here — it's not about having multiple jobs, but about being part of a community that supports one another in whatever way we can. I've always believed that work isn't just about earning a paycheck, but about contributing to something bigger, and I feel like I'm doing that, even if it's not in a traditional way.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 31 to 35 made me reflect on how much my emotional well-being and financial stability are intertwined with the people and routines that make up my life. Talking about my stress, coping strategies, and how I manage our household budget reminded me of how important it is to be honest about my limitations and to lean on the people I love. It also made me think about how my faith, though not always practiced in a traditional way, has been a quiet source of strength for me, especially during difficult times. I've come to understand that my worth isn't tied to being perfect or having everything together — it's about showing up for my family, being kind to myself, and finding comfort in the values that have shaped me. It's also made me more aware of how my financial situation, while not always easy, is something I manage with care and support from my community. These reflections have helped me see that my emotional and financial well-being are not separate things — they're both about being connected to the people and values that ground me, even when life feels overwhelming.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Elizabeth Ong: In total, our household made around $4,200 in the past month. Both my husband and I work full time, which helps, but it's still a tight budget. Michael earns a bit more than I do, so we split the expenses accordingly. I think what keeps us afloat is the fact that we're both committed to our jobs and to each other. We don't have a lot of luxuries, but we make do with what we have. I also feel lucky that I have a job I believe in — one that gives me purpose and allows me to help others, even if it's not always easy. It's not about having a lot of money, but about knowing that we're working together, and that we're doing the best we can for our kids and for our community.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Elizabeth Ong: I've been working at the community center for about seven years now, and it's become such a big part of my life. The benefits of the job are pretty standard — health insurance, which is a huge relief, especially with my back issues and the fact that I see a chiropractor regularly. We also get paid time off, which is something I've learned to use wisely, even if it's just a few days here and there to recharge. I don't get a lot of vacation days, but I do have sick time, which has been helpful when I've had flare-ups or needed to rest. What I appreciate most about the job, though, is the sense of purpose it gives me. I know that what I do here matters — whether it's helping a family find housing or just being there to listen to someone who feels like they're at their lowest. It's not always easy, but I feel like I'm making a difference, even in small ways. And honestly, that's what keeps me going — knowing that my work, however modest, is helping others just as my community helped me when I was growing up.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Elizabeth Ong: My relationships at work are pretty much like the ones I've always had — built on trust, support, and a shared sense of purpose. I've been lucky to have a manager who understands the weight of what we do here. She's not just focused on the numbers or the efficiency of our programs; she genuinely cares about the people we serve and the people who work here. She's been a great mentor to me, especially when I was starting out, and I always feel like I can talk to her about anything, whether it's a tough case or just needing someone to listen. As for my coworkers, we're a pretty close-knit group. We've been through a lot together — long hours, difficult cases, and the occasional frustration — but there's a real sense of camaraderie. We look out for each other, and I think that's what makes this job bearable, even on the hardest days. I've always believed that work shouldn't just be about doing a job — it should be about being part of something meaningful, and I feel that way here.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Elizabeth Ong: My work schedule is pretty predictable, but there's always a little room for flexibility, which I really appreciate. Most weeks, I have the same core hours — 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. — but depending on the needs of the community center, I might stay a bit later or come in a little earlier. Sometimes, if there's a support group that runs late or if I need to catch up on paperwork, I'll stay until 6 or 7. On other days, especially when I'm feeling up to it, I might leave a bit early to pick up the kids or take a walk. I think that flexibility is one of the things that makes this job work for me — it allows me to balance my responsibilities at work with the ones I have at home. It's not always perfect, but it gives me the freedom to be present for my family without feeling like I'm constantly rushing. I also know that when things get busy, I can rely on my coworkers to cover for me, which is something I'm really grateful for. It's that kind of support — both at work and at home — that helps me keep going, even on the hardest days.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Elizabeth Ong: Overall, I feel like we're managing, even if it's not always easy. I know we don't have a lot of money, but I also know that we're not alone in this. My husband and I both work hard, and we've learned to be careful with what we spend. I think the biggest thing that helps is knowing that we're part of a community that looks out for each other — whether it's my parents helping out with the kids or the people at the food pantry giving us a hand when we need it. I've always believed that financial stability isn't just about having a lot of money, but about knowing that you can count on the people around you. I'm not sure if I'd call it secure, but I feel like we're doing the best we can, and that's something I can be proud of.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 36 to 40 made me reflect on how much my financial stability and emotional well-being are intertwined with the rhythms of life and the support of my community. Talking about how our bills fluctuate throughout the year, from heating costs in the winter to utility expenses in the summer, reminded me of the importance of careful budgeting and the value of relying on the people around me. It also made me think about how saving, even in small amounts, gives me a sense of security and control in a world that can feel unpredictable. I've come to understand that financial stability isn't about having a lot, but about being prepared and knowing that I can count on my family, my job, and my community to help me through the ups and downs. It's comforting to know that even though we don't have a lot, we're doing the best we can — and that, in itself, is something to be proud of.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Elizabeth Ong: Yes, both my mom and dad worked for pay while I was growing up, though their jobs were different. My father worked as a mechanic, and he was always the one who kept our family running — fixing cars, doing odd jobs, and making sure we had a roof over our heads. He worked full time, and even though he only had an associate's degree, he was really good at what he did. My mother, on the other hand, worked part-time as a clerk at a local store, which wasn't a lot of money, but it helped. She always said she wanted to be there for us, even if it meant working long hours or taking on extra shifts. I remember her coming home tired but still making sure we had dinner ready and that our homework was done. I think their work ethic was something that shaped me — it showed me that even if you don't have a lot, you can still work hard and provide for your family. I also learned that their jobs weren't just about earning money — they were about responsibility, about showing up every day, and about doing what you can for the people you love. I carry that with me in my own work as a social worker — I know what it's like to need help, and I want to be the kind of person who shows up for others the way my parents showed up for me.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Elizabeth Ong: My father's job as a mechanic was more than just fixing cars — it was about problem-solving, patience, and knowing how to make things work again. He had a small shop in the back of his garage, and people from all over the neighborhood would bring their cars to him. He'd spend hours diagnosing issues, sometimes even staying up late to fix something that needed to be done before morning. He was always teaching me how things worked, whether it was the engine of a car or the way a simple lever could lift something heavy. My mother's job was different, but just as important. She worked as a clerk at a local store, and her days were filled with counting inventory, helping customers, and keeping the registers running smoothly. She always said that her job wasn't glamorous, but it gave her a sense of purpose — knowing that she was helping people get what they needed, even if it was just a loaf of bread or a bottle of milk. I think what I learned from both of them was that work isn't just about the paycheck — it's about showing up, doing your best, and taking pride in what you do, no matter how small it may seem.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Elizabeth Ong: My father worked for a small auto repair shop that was owned by a family friend, and he did most of his work out of his own garage. He was self-employed in a way, though he did take on some jobs through the shop as well. He made his own parts, fixed engines, and even did some custom work for people who wanted their cars to look a certain way. My mother worked at a local grocery store that was owned by an Irish-American family — the kind of place that felt like a second home to everyone in the neighborhood. She made sure the shelves were always stocked, the registers were working, and the customers felt welcome. She also helped out with the weekly inventory, which was a big task, but she did it with care. I think what I learned from both of them was that work wasn't just about making money — it was about being part of something bigger, about serving others, and about doing your best, even when life wasn't easy.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Elizabeth Ong: A few years from now, I hope I'm still here, still doing the work I believe in, and still raising my kids in the same neighborhood that shaped me. I hope they've grown into kind, resilient, and curious people — ones who know how to ask for help when they need it and how to give it when they can. I hope my back pain is under better control, and that I'm still able to walk to work, feel the sun on my face, and sit on my porch with my parents, just like I always have. I hope my husband and I are still building a life together, not because we have everything figured out, but because we're still trying, still learning, and still showing up for each other. I also hope that my work at the community center continues to make a difference — even if it's just one person at a time. I don't need to be rich or famous to feel like I've made an impact. I just want to know that I've helped someone feel seen, heard, and supported, just like I was when I was growing up. That, to me, is the kind of future I can be proud of.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Elizabeth Ong: What I value the most in my life is the people — my family, my friends, my community, and the people I get to help through my work. I think life is too short to be focused on things that don't matter, and I've learned that the most important things are the ones that bring you love, support, and a sense of belonging. I value the quiet strength of my parents, the way they worked hard to give us a life, even when they didn't have much. I value the way my husband has always been there for me, even when I wasn't perfect. I value the kids — their laughter, their curiosity, their resilience. I value the people I work with, who remind me every day why I chose this path. And I value the neighborhood I grew up in, the one that shaped me, the one that still feels like home. I think it's easy to get caught up in what we don't have, but I've come to realize that what truly matters is what we do have — the people who love us, the moments that make us feel connected, and the small, everyday acts of kindness that keep us going. That's what I value most — the people, the love, and the community that keeps me grounded.

Going through the recent interview topics from questions 41 to 45 made me reflect on how deeply my financial situation and work life are connected to the people and values that have shaped me. Talking about our household income, the predictability of my work schedule, and the relationships I have at work reminded me of how much I rely on both my job and my community to keep things balanced. I've come to understand that financial stability isn't about having a lot, but about knowing that I can count on my family, my coworkers, and the people I serve to help me through the challenges. It also made me think about how my work as a social worker is not just a job, but a way of giving back — just like my parents gave to me. I'm grateful for the flexibility my job offers, the support I receive from my manager and coworkers, and the fact that I'm still doing the work I believe in, even if it's not always easy. These reflections have helped me see that my life, while not perfect, is built on the things that matter most — love, connection, and the belief that we can all make a difference, no matter how small.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been a journey of reflection, not just about the events and choices that shaped me, but also about the people, values, and community that have been the foundation of my life. It reminded me how much I carry with me — the resilience of my parents, the strength of my family, the support of my friends, and the deep sense of belonging I have in this neighborhood. I've come to see that my life, with all its challenges and small victories, is a testament to the power of community, the importance of staying grounded, and the value of showing up for others, just as others showed up for me. It's not about being perfect or having everything figured out, but about being present, being kind, and being connected to the people and values that matter most. This interview has helped me see that my story is not just mine — it's part of something bigger, and that gives me strength, hope, and a deep sense of gratitude for the life I've built.
